title: How to Prepare Idli Batter

methods.name: Preparing Soft Idli Batter in a Wet Grinder

steps.headline: Rinse the idli rice 3 or 4 times in cold water.
steps.description: Measure 4 cups (700 g) of idli rice into a large bowl and fill it with cold water. Use a spoon or your hand to swish the rice around. Drain the water out and pour clean water into the bowl. Continue to swish and drain the water until it's clear. Rinsing the rice will make the idlis whiter.

steps.headline: Soak the idli rice for 3 to 5 hours.
steps.description: Pour enough clean water into the bowl to cover the rice. Soak the rice at room temperature for 3 to 5 hours so it swells and softens. You don't need to measure the water because you'll drain it before grinding the rice.

steps.headline: Soak the urad dal for 3 to 4 hours.
steps.description: Measure 1 cup (200 g) of urad dal into a separate bowl. Fill it with clean water so the dal is covered. Soak the dal at room temperature until it softens. There's no need to measure the water because you'll be draining it off.

steps.headline: Soak the fenugreek seeds in a small bowl for 3 to 4 hours.
steps.description: If you're using the fenugreek seeds, measure 1 tablespoon (11 g) of fenugreek seeds (Vendhayam) into a small bowl and pour enough water to cover the seeds. Soak them at room temperature for 3 to 4 hours.

steps.headline: Grind the fenugreek seeds with water for 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Drain the soaked fenugreek seeds into a fine mesh strainer in the sink. Place the seeds into the wet grinder and pour in 1/2 cup (120 ml) of water. Turn the wet grinder on and grind the seeds for 3 to 4 minutes. The seeds should become completely ground into a smooth paste.

steps.headline: Drain the urad dal and add it to the wet grinder with 1/2 cup (120 ml) of water.
steps.description: Pour the soaked urad dal through the strainer and transfer the dal to the grinder with the fenugreek. Add another 1/2 cup (120 ml) of water to the wet grinder.

steps.headline: Grind the urad dal with the fenugreek for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the wet grinder on and leave it running for 30 minutes. The dal and fenugreek should become completely smooth. The amount should also increase by 8 to 10 times.

steps.headline: Transfer the ground dal and place the drained rice in the grinder.
steps.description: Scoop the ground dal mixture into a large bowl and set it aside. Drain the soaked idli rice through the strainer and transfer the rice to the wet grinder.

steps.headline: Grind the idli rice with 1 cup (240 ml) of water for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Pour the water into the grinder with the rice and turn the grinder on. Grind the rice until it's completely smooth. Turn off the wet grinder and transfer the ground rice to the bowl with the dal.

steps.headline: Mix the ground dal, ground rice, and salt.
steps.description: Measure 2 tablespoons (34 g) of salt into the bowl with the ground dal and rice. Stir the batter until it's smooth and combined.

steps.headline: Ferment the batter for 8 to 12 hours.
steps.description: Cover the bowl with the batter and keep it out at room temperature overnight. The batter needs to ferment for at least 8 to 12 hours. Place the batter in a warm place (such as in an oven that's turned off with the oven light on). The batter will double in size once it's fermented enough

steps.headline: Use the batter to make idlis.
steps.description: Heat your steamer and fill an idli mold with your batter. Lower the mold into the steamer and cook the idlis for 6 to 7 minutes. Remove the idlis and let them rest for 5 minutes before you serve them. Refrigerate leftover cooked idlis in an airtight container for up to 2 days.

methods.name: Making Soft Idli Batter in a Blender

steps.headline: Rinse the idli rice 2 or 3 times.
steps.description: Pour 4 cups (700 g) of idli rice into a large bowl and fill it with cold water. Swish the rice around with a spoon or your hand. Drain the water out and fill it with clean water. Continue to swish and drain the water until it's clear.

steps.headline: Soak the idli rice for 3 to 4 hours.
steps.description: Fill the bowl of rinsed idli rice with clean water so the rice is covered. Set it aside at room temperature and soak the rice for 3 to 4 hours so it softens. Don't worry about measuring the water since you'll drain it off.

steps.headline: Soak the urad dal for 3 to 4 hours.
steps.description: Get out a separate bowl and measure 1¼ cups (250 g) of urad dal into it. Fill the bowl with clean water so the dal is covered. Soak the dal at room temperature until it softens. You don't need to measure the water in the bowl since you'll drain it once the dal is soaked.

steps.headline: Soak the poha for 3 to 4 hours.
steps.description: Get out another bowl and measure 1 1/2 cups (221 g) of thick poha into it. Measure and stir in 2 cups (473 ml) of water into the poha. Set the poha aside at room temperature to soak for 3 to 4 hours. You have to measure the water into the poha since you'll be including it in the batter.

steps.headline: Soak the fenugreek seeds in a small bowl for 3 to 4 hours.
steps.description: Place 1 tablespoon (11 g) of fenugreek seeds (Vendhayam) into a small prep bowl. Pour in 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of water and soak the seeds at room temperature for 3 to 4 hours.

steps.headline: Blend the fenugreek seeds with the poha and water for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Drain the soaked fenugreek seeds through a strainer and place the seeds into your blender or mixer. Add the soaked poha with its soaking liquid. Add 1 cup (240 ml) of water and put the lid on the blender. Blend the mixture for 3 minutes and then transfer it to a storage container. The mixture should be smoothly ground and slightly fluffy.

steps.headline: Blend the drained urad dal with ice water for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Set a fine mesh strainer in the sink and pour the soaked urad dal through it. Transfer the dal to the blender and pour in 1 cup (240 ml) of ice water. Put the lid on the blender and blend the mixture for 3 minutes. Pour the mixture into the storage container with the ground poha mixture. The ground dal should be completely smooth. The ice water will prevent the batter from fermenting too quickly.

steps.headline: Blend the drained idli rice with water.
steps.description: Pour the soaked idli rice through the strainer in the sink. Place about 1/3 of the rice into the blender and pour in about 1/2 cup (120 ml) of water. Cover the blender and blend it until it's smooth. Pour the mixture into the storage container and finish blending the rest of the rice. Blend the rest of the rice in batches. For example, add another 1/3 of the rice into the blender with another 1/2 cup (120 ml) of water.

steps.headline: Stir salt into the batter with your hands.
steps.description: Measure 2 tablespoons (34 g) of salt into the storage container with the batter. Use your hands to mix the batter until the salt is incorporated. The batter should have the consistency of a thick paste. Most Indian recipes call for mixing the batter with your hands so the heat from your hands warms the batter. If you prefer, you can use a large spoon instead.

steps.headline: Rest the batter at room temperature for 8 to 10 hours.
steps.description: Cover the storage container with a lid or plastic wrap and let the batter ferment overnight. To keep the batter warm, consider wrapping a blanket around the container. The batter should double in size once it's finished fermenting. While there's no specific temperature at which you should ferment the batter, it will take longer to ferment if the room is too cold. Consider placing the container in an oven that's turned off. Turn on the oven light to create a little heat.

steps.headline: Refrigerate or use the batter to make idlis.
steps.description: Use a large spoon to stir the fermented batter. To make the idlis, prepare a steamer and fill an idli mold with batter. Steam the idlis for 8 to 10 minutes until they're soft. If you want to store the batter for later, refrigerate it for up to 3 days. Cooked idlis can be stored for up to 2 days in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Measure semolina, yogurt, asafoetida, baking soda, and salt into a bowl.
steps.description: Place 1 1/4 cup (208 g) of semolina (coarse sooji) into a large mixing bowl and add 1 cup (245 g) of plain yogurt. Add 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) of baking soda, 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) of asafoetida, and salt according to your taste. If you want to prepare the batter in advance, wait until you're ready to steam the idlis before you stir in the baking soda.

steps.headline: Whisk in the water.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (240 ml) of water into the mixing bowl and use a whisk to combine the batter. Keep whisking until it's completely smooth and combined.

steps.headline: Cover and rest the batter for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and set it aside at room temperature. The baking soda will activate and create bubbles which will help the idlis rise.

steps.headline: Use the batter to make 20 idlis.
steps.description: Prepare a steamer and grease your idli mold. Fill the mold cavities with the instant idli batter and steam them for 8 to 10 minutes. Lift the idli mold and brush the steamed idlis with oil before you serve them. Store the leftover idlis in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 1 or 2 days. Refrigerate the leftover idli batter for 1 to 2 days. When you're ready to steam the idlis, stir in the baking soda.
